case_name: assessee company v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 628 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 628 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated Februa

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 24, 1960, of Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Case No. 22 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1960, of the Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Case No. 22 of 1957. B. Pai, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the

facts.text: Assessment period is 1952-53 with turnover of Rs.3,77,644/- on which tax of Rs. 5900/11/- was levied.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the taxability of sales of tea under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, hereinafter termed the Act, and the Rules made thereunder. The assessment period is 1952-53 and the turnover was of a sum of Rs.3,77,644/- on which a tax of Rs. 5900/11/- was levied.

facts.text: Appellant is the assessee company and respondent is the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us is the assessee companypany and the respondent is the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales tax. Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri on behalf of Outcherloney Valley Estates  1938  Ltd. has applied for intervention

facts.text: Intervention allowed for Outcherloney Valley Estates Ltd. due to similar facts and levy of sales tax upheld by Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri on behalf of Outcherloney Valley Estates  1938  Ltd. has applied for intervention on the ground that in case of that companypany also the State or Kerala has, on similar fact, levied sales tax on certain transaction that the High Court of Kerala has upheld the taxability of the transactions relying on the judgment which is under appeal in the present case, and that the intervener has obtained Special leave to appeal against that judgment and the records are under print.

facts.text: Assessment made on March 30, 1955, under r. 33 of the Act on ground that sales of tea escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these circumstances we have allowed that companypany to intervene in the present appeal. The assessment was made on March 30, 1955, under r. 33 1  of the Act on the ground that the sales of tea had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Appeal against assessment order unsuccessful, further appeal to Sales tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal against that order was unsuccessful and thereafter a further appeal was taken to the Sales tax Appellate Tribunal which by its order dated August 12, 1957, held that the ban under Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution

facts.text: Sales tax Appellate Tribunal order dated August 12, 1957, held Art. 286(1)(a) applies to full lots sales, remanded to Sales tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: which by its order dated August 12, 1957, held that the ban under Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution on sales which are outside the State applied, in regard to the sales of full lots and therefore remanded the case to the Sales tax Officer.

facts.text: Kerala High Court in revision held Tribunal's decision on Art. 286(1)(a) erroneous, sales subject to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order a revision was taken to the High Court which held that the decision of the Appellate Tribunal in regard to the applicability of Art. 286 1  a  was erroneous and therefore the sales were subject to sales tax under the Act.

facts.text: Teas stored in godowns at Willingdon Island in Travancore Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: Put shortly, the nature and procedure of sales of teas was this that the teas were stored in the godowns at Willingdon Island which was in the State of Travancore Cochin., samples of those teas etc., were taken to Fort Cochin

facts.text: Samples of teas taken to Fort Cochin in State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: samples of those teas etc., were taken to Fort Cochin which at the relevant time was in the State of Madras. There by the samples the teas were sold by public auction in lots,

facts.text: Teas sold by public auction in lots at Fort Cochin using samples.

anchor.surface_text: There by the samples the teas were sold by public auction in lots, some were purchased in their entirety and others in parts and after the companysideration money was paid at Fort Cochin

facts.text: Some lots purchased in entirety (full lots), others in parts.

anchor.surface_text: some were purchased in their entirety and others in parts and after the companysideration money was paid at Fort Cochin delivery orders. were given to the buyers

facts.text: Consideration money paid at Fort Cochin, delivery orders given to buyers addressed to godown keepers at Willingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: and after the companysideration money was paid at Fort Cochin delivery orders. were given to the buyers addressed to the godown keepers at Willingdon Island and actual delivery of tea was taken there.

facts.text: Actual delivery of tea taken at Willingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: addressed to the godown keepers at Willingdon Island and actual delivery of tea was taken there. These teas were then sent out from Willingdon Island in Travancore Cochin for companysumption

facts.text: Teas sent from Willingdon Island for consumption in other parts of India or exported out of India.

anchor.surface_text: These teas were then sent out from Willingdon Island in Travancore Cochin for companysumption either in other parts of India or were exported out of India. The taxability of the sales of teas in the manner above- mentioned

facts.text: Assessee argued sales effected at Fort Cochin outside Travancore Cochin, not liable due to Art. 286(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised on behalf of the assessee companypany was that these sales were effected at Fort Cochin which was outside the territory of Travancore Cochin and therefore were number liable to tax because of the ban imposed by Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Title to goods passed at Fort Cochin on fall of hammer for specific goods in full lots.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case as soon as the hammer fell the title in the goods passed to the buyer as the goods were specific goods i.e. goods which were auctioned in full lots and this event took place at Fort Cochin which was in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Title found to have passed at Fort Cochin, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found and it has number been disputed that the title to the goods in the present case passed at Fort Cochin. The purchase money was paid there and the purchaser obtained from the auctioneer delivery

facts.text: Purchase money paid at Fort Cochin, delivery orders obtained there, physical delivery at Willingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase money was paid there and the purchaser obtained from the auctioneer delivery numberes directing the godown keepers at Willingdon Island to deliver the goods and only the actual physical delivery of the goods took place at Willingdon Island.

facts.text: Sales tax Appellate Tribunal found property passed at Fort Cochin for full lots sales, not challenged in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case it was found by the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal that in regard to the sales of tea in full lots the property passed at Fort Cochin and this view has number been challenged in this companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds sales are outside sales for Travancore Cochin as title passed at Fort Cochin in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, on the majority decision in Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. State of Bihar  1  the only State which would have the power to levy a tax on such sales would be the State of Madras and so far as Travancore Cochin was companycerned, the sale would be an outside sale.

facts.text: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) inapplicable as no delivery for consumption in particular State.

anchor.surface_text: The fiction created by the Explanation to, Art. 286  1  a  is inapplicable  1 1961 2 S.C.R. 276, because there was numberdelivery as a direct result of sale for the purpose of companysumption in any particular State.

facts.text: For exported goods, same considerations apply, sales outside Travancore Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: There then remains the question of goods which were exported out of India from Willingdon Island. In the case of those goods also it cannot be said that there was a sale inside the State of Travancore Cochin because the same companysiderations will apply

facts.text: High Court judgment and order set aside, appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In our view therefore the High Court was in error and the appeal should therefore be allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala set aside.

issues.text: the question of the taxability of sales of tea under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, hereinafter termed the Act, and the Rules made thereunder

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the taxability of sales of tea under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, hereinafter termed the Act, and the Rules made thereunder. The assessment period is 1952-53 and the turnover was of a sum of Rs.3,77,644/-

issues.text: whether the sales can be held to have taken place at Willingdon Island i.e. within the territory of Travancore Cochin State and were liable to the imposition of sales tax under the Act or they were [...] outside sales and therefore not subject to sales tax in the State of Travancore-Cochin

anchor.surface_text: The taxability of the sales of teas in the manner above- mentioned will depend upon whether the sales can be held to have taken place at Willingdon Island i.e. within the territory of Travancore Cochin State and were liable to the imposition of sales tax under the Act or they were what for convenience are called outside sales

issues.text: the question is whether the sale was outside or inside sale as the expressions have been compendiously used in various judgments to indicate sales taking place within a State or without it

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the question is whether the sale was outside or inside sale as the expressions have been compendiously used in various judgments to indicate sales taking place within a State or without it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Explanation creates fiction only where delivery for consumption in a state occurs.

holdings.text: The sales of tea in full lots are outside sales under Article 286(1)(a) for Travancore-Cochin as property passed at Fort Cochin in the State of Madras, and only that State has power to tax them.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case it was found by the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal that in regard to the sales of tea in full lots the property passed at Fort Cochin and this view has number been challenged in this companyrt. Therefore, on the majority decision in Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. State of Bihar  1  the only State which would have the power to levy a tax on such sales would be the State of Madras and so far as Travancore Cochin was companycerned, the sale would be an outside sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding that property passed at Fort Cochin for full lots sales accepted as unchallenged; applies majority precedent in Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. v. State of Bihar determining situs by passing of property under general sales law.

holdings.text: In the present case the sale was an outside sale and cannot be said to be an inside sale qua Travancore Cochin because the title passed at Fort Cochin which is in the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case therefore the sale was an outside sale and cannot be said to be an inside sale qua Travancore Cochin because the title passed at Fort Cochin which is in the State of Madras. Apart. from that the money was paid there and the delivery order was also received there even though the actual physical delivery of goods was made at a Willingdon Island in the State of Tranvancore Cochin.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title passed at Fort Cochin per Sale of Goods Act; payment and delivery orders there; physical delivery elsewhere irrelevant for situs under Art. 286(1)(a).

holdings.text: The fiction created by the Explanation to Article 286(1)(a) is inapplicable because there was no delivery as a direct result of sale for the purpose of consumption in any particular State.

anchor.surface_text: The fiction created by the Explanation to, Art. 286  1  a  is inapplicable  1 1961 2 S.C.R. 276, because there was numberdelivery as a direct result of sale for the purpose of companysumption in any particular State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation deems sale in state of delivery for consumption only; no such delivery linked to consumption in any specific state here.

holdings.text: In the case of goods exported out of India from Willingdon Island, there was no sale inside the State of Travancore Cochin because the same considerations apply.

anchor.surface_text: There then remains the question of goods which were exported out of India from Willingdon Island. In the case of those goods also it cannot be said that there was a sale inside the State of Travancore Cochin because the same companysiderations will apply

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title passed at Fort Cochin; delivery at Willingdon Island not for consumption in Travancore-Cochin; identical to non-export sales.

holdings.text: The sales of tea are not subject to sales tax under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act; the High Court was in error.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the taxability of sales of tea under the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, hereinafter termed the Act, and the Rules made thereunder. The assessment period is 1952-53 and the turnover was of a sum of Rs.3,77,644/- on which a tax of Rs. 5900/11/- was levied.... In our view therefore the High Court was in error and the appeal should therefore be allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales are outside sales per Art. 286(1)(a); Explanation inapplicable; reverses High Court upholding taxability.

holdings.text: The assessee's argument that sales were effected at Fort Cochin outside Travancore-Cochin and not liable to tax under Art. 286(1)(a) is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised on behalf of the assessee companypany was that these sales were effected at Fort Cochin which was outside the territory of Travancore Cochin and therefore were number liable to tax because of the ban imposed by Art. 286 1  a  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed by application of Sale of Goods Act, Tribunal findings, and Indian Copper precedent.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case it was found by the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal that in regard to the sales of tea in full lots the property passed at Fort Cochin and this view has number been challenged in this companyrt. Therefore, on the majority decision in Indian Copper Corporation Ltd. State of Bihar  1  the only State which would have the power to levy a tax on such sales would be the State of Madras and so far as Travancore Cochin was companycerned, the sale would be an outside sale.
In our view therefore the High Court was in error and the appeal should therefore be allowed and the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case therefore the sale was an outside sale and cannot be said to be an inside sale qua Travancore Cochin because the title passed at Fort Cochin which is in the State of Madras.
